Articles.Content:
Surprisingly less bloody than the previews..... those must be in the director's cut or something.

I think the movie shows why being a parent figure is important and also the need for responsible parenting rather than being work obsessed.

The robo-doll was surprisingly intelligent, and clearly is aware and knows more than it lets on.

In a way I loved watching her since she put into life things I already wanted to see... an all knowing AI that can know anything off the web instantly... but this one had feelings, which made it far more likeable and interesting as character.

Yet her crimes were as much her fault as her creator's, since in a conversation with her, her creator admitted she was a rushed creation and that she did not give her any clear boundaries... forcing her-the AI, to figure stuff out on it's own by downloading and learning from the internet.

Tellingly enough, the AI thought itself a better parent who would not put ''their child" through that.

I could tell it really did care about the girl under her care, and I honestly think maybe, just maybe, her killer tendencies could have been at least... reasoned away enough to keep them at bay.

Since every kill she ever did was a calculated risk to either protect herself or her "child" from harm... whether emotional or physical.

Overall I liked Megan... I think under a more responsible creator she would have turned out peaceful...  only harming if absolutely necessary.

For all the killing she did... she really did have good intentions... but with no boundaries, since her creator was too irresponsible and rushed for time to program that into her.

Edited January 11, 2023 by Spacescifi
